props.name: Space frame - Wikipedia
props.author: Wikipedia Contributors
props.text:
Rigid three dimensional load bearing truss structure

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/ITP_Zamudio.jpg/225px-ITP_Zamudio.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:ITP_Zamudio.jpg)

The roof of this industrial building is supported by a space frame structure.

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Articulacion_malla.svg/225px-Articulacion_malla.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Articulacion_malla.svg)

If a force is applied to the blue node and the red bar were _not_ present, the resultant effect on the structure would depend entirely on the blue node's bending rigidity, _i.e._ to its resistance (or lack thereof) to bending; however, with the red bar in place, then assuming negligible bending rigidity of the blue node as compared with the red bar's contributing rigidity, this 3-dimensional load-bearing truss structure could be solved using a rigidity matrix (neglecting angular factors).

In [architecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Architecture) and [structural engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Structural_engineering), a **space frame** or **space structure** ([3D](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three-dimensional_space) [truss](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Truss)) is a rigid, lightweight, truss-like structure constructed from interlocking [struts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strut) in a [geometric](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geometry) [pattern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pattern). Space frames can be used to span large areas with few interior supports. Like the truss, a space frame is strong because of the inherent rigidity of the triangle; flexing [loads](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Structural_load) (bending [moments](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moment_\(physics\))) are transmitted as [tension](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tension_\(mechanics\)) and [compression](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compression_\(physical\)) loads along the length of each strut.

Chief applications include buildings and vehicles.

  
Space frames are strong, adaptable, and efficient buildings that can support a variety of weights. For their effective implementation in construction, it is important to comprehend their behavior under various loads, probable modes of failure, and rules for optimal arrangement. To maximize space frames' performance and longevity, proper design, material selection, and joint integrity are essential.

[Alexander Graham Bell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Graham_Bell) from 1898 to 1908 developed space frames based on tetrahedral geometry.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_frame#cite_note-1)[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_frame#cite_note-2) Bell's interest was primarily in using them to make rigid frames for nautical and aeronautical engineering, with the [tetrahedral truss](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tetrahedral_kite) being one of his inventions.

[Max Mengeringhausen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mero-Schmidlin) developed the space grid system called MERO (acronym of _**ME**ngeringhausen **RO**hrbauweise_) in 1943 in Germany, thus initiating the use of space trusses in architecture.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_frame#cite_note-3) The commonly used method, still in use has individual tubular members connected at node joints (ball shaped) and variations such as the space deck system, octet truss system and cubic system.

Stéphane de Chateau in France invented the Tridirectional SDC system (1957), Unibat system (1959), Pyramitec (1960).[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_frame#cite_note-4)[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_frame#cite_note-5) A method of tree supports was developed to replace the individual columns.[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_frame#cite_note-6)

[Buckminster Fuller](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buckminster_Fuller) patented the octet truss ([U.S. patent 2,986,241](https://patents.google.com/patent/US2986241)) in 1961[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_frame#cite_note-7) while focusing on [architectural](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Architecture) structures.

[Gilman's Tetrahedral Truss](https://patentimages.storage.googleapis.com/1c/9a/7a/6aa02cf0efb93c/US4446666.pdf) of 1980 was developed by [John J. Gilman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_J._Gilman); a material scientist known for his work on the molecular matrices of crystalline solids. Gilman was an admirer of Buckminster Fuller's architectural trusses, and developed a stronger matrix, in part by rotating an alignment of tetrahedral nodes in relation to each other.

Space frames are typically designed using a rigidity matrix. The special characteristic of the [stiffness matrix](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stiffness_matrix) in an architectural space frame is the independence of the angular factors. If the joints are sufficiently rigid, the angular deflections can be neglected, simplifying the calculations.

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/SpaceFrame02.png/250px-SpaceFrame02.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:SpaceFrame02.png)

Simplified space frame roof with the half-octahedron highlighted in blue

The simplest form of space frame is a horizontal slab of interlocking [square pyramids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Square_pyramid) and [tetrahedra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tetrahedron) built from [Aluminium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aluminium) or tubular [steel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steel) struts. In many ways this looks like the horizontal jib of a tower crane repeated many times to make it wider. A stronger form is composed of interlocking [tetrahedra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tetrahedron) in which all the struts have unit length. More technically this is referred to as an isotropic vector matrix or in a single unit width an octet truss. More complex variations change the lengths of the struts to curve the overall structure or may incorporate other geometrical shapes.

Within the meaning of space frame, we can find three systems clearly different between them:[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_frame#cite_note-ref1-8)

**Curvature classification**

*   Space plane covers: These spatial structures are composed of planar substructures. Their behavior is similar to that of a plate in which the deflections in the plane are channeled through the horizontal bars and the shear forces are supported by the diagonals.[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_frame#cite_note-ref5-9)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Tirumailai_MRTS_station_Chennai_%28Madras%29.jpg/250px-Tirumailai_MRTS_station_Chennai_%28Madras%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Tirumailai_MRTS_station_Chennai_\(Madras\).jpg)

This train station in India is supported by a barrel vault structure

*   Barrel vaults: This type of vault has a cross section of a simple arch. Usually this type of space frame does not need to use tetrahedral modules or pyramids as a part of its backing. The section type barrel vault is organized according to IS: 800-2007, and the evaluation is carried out mostly using STAAD. This work elicit evaluations of models for range, extreme redirection, self-weight, and cost.[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_frame#cite_note-10)
*   Spherical domes and other compound curves usually require the use of tetrahedral modules or pyramids and additional support from a skin.

**Classification by the arrangement of its elements**

*   Single layer grid: All elements are located on the surface to be approximated.
*   Double layer grid: Elements are organized in two layers parallel to each other at a certain distance apart. Each of the layers form a lattice of triangles, squares or hexagons in which the projection of the nodes in a layer may overlap or be displaced relative to each other. Diagonal bars connect the nodes of both layers in different directions in space. In this type of meshes, the elements are associated into three groups: upper cordon, cordon and cordon lower diagonal.
*   Triple layer grid: Elements are placed in three parallel layers, linked by the diagonals. They are almost always flat.

Other examples classifiable as space frames are these:

*   Pleated metallic structures: Emerged to try to solve the problems that formwork and pouring concrete had their counterparts. Typically run with welded joint, but may raise prefabricated joints, a fact which makes them space meshes.
*   Hanging covers: Designs on the cable taut, spine, and the [catenary arch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catenary_arch) ([inverted funicular](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Funicular_curve) show their ability to channel forces theoretically better than any other alternative, have an infinite range of possibilities for composition and adaptability to any type of plant cover or ensure vain. However, imprecisions in shape having the loaded strand (ideally adapts dynamically to the state of charge) and the risk of bending the arc to unexpected stresses are problems that require pre-compression and pre-stressing elements. Although in most cases tend to be the cheapest and the technical solution that best fits the acoustics and ventilation of the covered enclosure, are vulnerable to vibration.
*   Pneumatic structures: Closure membranes subjected to a pressurized state may be considered within this group.

Chief space frame applications include:

**Buildings**

*   Industrial structures:
    *   [Factories](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Factory)
    *   [Warehouses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warehouse),
*   Commercial, entertainment, and service facilities:
    *   [Sports halls](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sports_hall)
    *   Conference halls, pavilions, and [exhibition centers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exhibition_center)
    *   [Stadiums](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stadium)
    *   [Museums](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum) and fair houses
    *   [Shopping malls](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shopping_mall)
    *   [Airports](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airport)

**[Vehicles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_frame#Vehicles)**:

*   *   Aircraft
    *   Automobiles
    *   Motorcycles
    *   Bicycles
    *   Spacecraft

**Architectural design elements**

*   *   [Atriums](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atrium_\(architecture\))
    *   [Geodesics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geodesic)

Space frames are a common feature in modern building construction; they are often found in large roof spans in [modernist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modernism) commercial and industrial buildings.

Examples of buildings based on space frames include:

*   [Stansted Airport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stansted_Airport), by [Foster + Partners](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foster_%2B_Partners)
*   [Bank of China Tower](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_China_Tower,_Hong_Kong) and the [Louvre Pyramid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louvre_Pyramid), by [I. M. Pei](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I._M._Pei)
*   [Rogers Centre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rogers_Centre) by [Rod Robbie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rod_Robbie) and [Michael Allan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Allen_\(architect\))
*   [McCormick Place](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McCormick_Place) East in [Chicago](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago)
*   [Arena das Dunas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arena_das_Dunas) in Natal, Brazil by [Populous](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Populous_\(company\))
*   [Eden Project](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eden_Project) in Cornwall, England
*   [Globen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ericsson_Globe), Sweden - Dome with diameter of 110 m, (1989)

Large portable stages and lighting [gantries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crane_\(machine\)#Gantry) are also frequently built from space frames and octet trusses.

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Yeoman_YA-1_vs_CA-6_Wackett_frame.jpg/220px-Yeoman_YA-1_vs_CA-6_Wackett_frame.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Yeoman_YA-1_vs_CA-6_Wackett_frame.jpg)

Yeoman YA-1 vs CA-6 Wackett frames.

The [CAC CA-6 Wackett](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CAC_Wackett) and [Yeoman YA-1 Cropmaster 250R](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yeoman_Cropmaster) aircraft were built using roughly the same welded steel tube fuselage frame.

Many early “whirlybird”-style exposed-boom helicopters had tubular space frame booms, such as the [Bell 47](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bell_47) series.

Space frames are sometimes used in the chassis designs of [automobiles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automobiles) and [motorcycles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motorcycles). In both a space frame and a tube-frame chassis, the suspension, engine, and body panels are attached to a skeletal frame of tubes, and the body panels have little or no structural function. By contrast, in a [unibody](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unibody) or [monocoque](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monocoque) design, the body serves as part of the structure.

Tube-frame chassis pre-date space frame chassis and are a development of the earlier [ladder chassis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ladder_chassis). The advantage of using tubes rather than the previous open channel sections is that they resist [torsional](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torsion_\(mechanics\)) forces better. Some tube chassis were little more than a ladder chassis made with two large diameter tubes, or even a single tube as a [backbone chassis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backbone_chassis). Although many tubular chassis developed additional tubes and were even described as "space frames", their design was rarely correctly stressed as a space frame and they behaved mechanically as a tube ladder chassis, with additional brackets to support the attached components, suspension, engine etc. The distinction of the true space frame is that all the forces in each strut are either tensile or compression, never bending.[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_frame#cite_note-Ludvigsen,_Colin_Chapman,_153-11) Although these additional tubes did carry some extra load, they were rarely diagonalised into a rigid space frame.[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_frame#cite_note-Ludvigsen,_Colin_Chapman,_153-11)

An earlier contender for the first true space frame chassis is the one off Chamberlain 8 race "special" built by brothers Bob and Bill Chamberlain in Melbourne, Australia in 1929.[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_frame#cite_note-12) Others attribute vehicles produced in the 1930s by designers such as [Buckminster Fuller](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buckminster_Fuller) and [William Bushnell Stout](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Bushnell_Stout) (the [Dymaxion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dymaxion_car) and the [Stout Scarab](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stout_Scarab)) who understood the theory of the true space frame from either architecture or aircraft design.[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_frame#cite_note-Ludvigsen,_Colin_Chapman,_150-13)

A post WW2 attempt to build a racing car space frame was the [Cisitalia D46](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cisitalia_D46) of 1946.[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_frame#cite_note-Ludvigsen,_Colin_Chapman,_150-13) This used two small diameter tubes along each side, but they were spaced apart by vertical smaller tubes, and so were not diagonalised in any plane. A year later, Porsche designed their [Type 360](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Porsche_360) for [Cisitalia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cisitalia). As this included diagonal tubes, it can be considered a true space frame and arguable the first mid-rear engined design.[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_frame#cite_note-Ludvigsen,_Colin_Chapman,_150-13)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Jaguar_C-Type_Frame.JPG/220px-Jaguar_C-Type_Frame.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Jaguar_C-Type_Frame.JPG)

[Jaguar C-Type](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaguar_C-Type) frame

The [Maserati Tipo 61](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maserati_Tipo_61) of 1959 (Birdcage) is often thought of as the first but in 1949 [Robert Eberan von Eberhorst](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Eberan_von_Eberhorst) designed the [Jowett Jupiter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jowett_Jupiter) exhibited at that year's [London Motor Show](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London_Motor_Show); the Jowett went on to take a class win at the 1950 Le Mans 24hr. Later, [TVR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TVR), the small British car manufacturers developed the concept and produced an alloy-bodied two seater on a multi tubular chassis, which appeared in 1949.

[Colin Chapman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colin_Chapman) of [Lotus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lotus_Cars) introduced his first 'production' car, the [Mark VI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lotus_Mark_VI), in 1952. This was influenced by the [Jaguar C-Type](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaguar_C-Type) chassis, another with four tubes of two different diameters, separated by narrower tubes. Chapman reduced the main tube diameter for the lighter Lotus, but did not reduce the minor tubes any further, possibly because he considered that this would appear flimsy to buyers.[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_frame#cite_note-Ludvigsen,_Colin_Chapman,_153-11) Although widely described as a space frame, Lotus did not build a true space frame chassis until the [Mark VIII](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lotus_Mark_VIII), with the influence of other designers, with experience from the aircraft industry.[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_frame#cite_note-Ludvigsen,_Colin_Chapman,_153-11)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Kitcar_%288906407466%29.jpg/220px-Kitcar_%288906407466%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Kitcar_\(8906407466\).jpg)

Chilean kitcar showing off its space frame structure (2013).

A large number of [kit cars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kit_car) use space frame construction, because manufacture in small quantity requires only simple and inexpensive [jigs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jig_\(tool\)), and it is relatively easy for an amateur designer to achieve good stiffness with a space frame.

A drawback of the space frame chassis is that it encloses much of the working volume of the car and can make access for both the driver and to the engine difficult. The [Mercedes-Benz 300 SL](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_300_SL) “Gullwing” received its iconic upward-opening doors when its tubular space frame made using regular doors impossible.

Some space frames have been designed with removable sections, joined by bolted pin joints. Such a structure had already been used around the engine of the [Lotus Mark III](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lotus_Mark_III).[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_frame#cite_note-Ludvigsen,_Colin_Chapman,_151-14) Although somewhat inconvenient, an advantage of the space frame is that the same lack of bending forces in the tubes that allow it to be modelled as a [pin-jointed structure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pin-jointed_truss) also means that creating such a removable section need not reduce the strength of the assembled frame.

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Moulton_%40_the_MoMA.jpg/220px-Moulton_%40_the_MoMA.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Moulton_@_the_MoMA.jpg)

[Moulton Bicycle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moulton_Bicycle) at the [Museum of Modern Art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Modern_Art)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/S2R1000-101_v2_1024_web.jpg/220px-S2R1000-101_v2_1024_web.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:S2R1000-101_v2_1024_web.jpg)

2006 [Ducati](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ducati) Monster S2R 1000

Italian motorbike manufacturer [Ducati](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ducati) extensively uses tube frame chassis on its models.

Space frames have also been used in [bicycles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bicycle), which readily favor stressed triangular sectioning.
